review.title: Computing sets of graded attribute implications with witnessed non-redundancy
review.abstract: In this paper we extend our previous results on sets of graded attribute implications with witnessed non-redundancy. We assume finite residuated lattices as structures of truth degrees and use arbitrary idempotent truth-stressing linguistic hedges as parameters which influence the semantics of graded attribute implications. In this setting, we introduce algorithm which transforms any set of graded attribute implications into an equivalent non-redundant set of graded attribute implications with saturated consequents whose non-redundancy is witnessed by antecedents of the formulas. As a consequence, we solve the open problem regarding the existence of general systems of pseudo-intents which appear in formal concept analysis of object-attribute data with graded attributes and linguistic hedges. Furthermore, we show a polynomial-time procedure for determining bases given by general systems of pseudo-intents from sets of graded attribute implications which are complete in data.

metadata.title: Computing sets of graded attribute implications with witnessed non-redundancy

sections.text: ar Xiv: 151 1.01 640v 1 [cs.A I] In this paper, we expand our previous results to include sets of graduated attribute implications with proven non-redundancy. We start from finite residual grids as structures of degrees of truth and use arbitrary idempotent, truth-emphasizing linguistic hedges as parameters that influence the semantics of graduated attribute implications. In this context, we introduce an algorithm that transforms each set of graduated attribute implications into an equivalent set of graduated attribute implications with saturated consequences whose non-redundancy is demonstrated by ancestors of the formulas. As a result, we solve the open problem regarding the existence of general systems of pseudo-coordinated intentions that arise in the formal concept analysis of object attribute data with graduated attribute data and linguistic hedges. Furthermore, we show a polynomic method of determining the basic time bases given by the graduated hedges.

sections.heading: 4 Proofs and notes
sections.text: In this section we present the proof of theorem 1 and present further notes, including an illustrative example and some experimental observations, which show that in the case of hedges other than globalization, non-redundant foundations given by systems of pseudo-intentions may be smaller. To prove the main contention of the work, we assume that L is a finite residuated structure, which is (3) - (6).Lemma 4. If this is the case, then we assume that the properties of paper (4) C and C D have such a finite structure derived from the form (18) results from A B and the addition of formula A (S) S (C, A) S (A), A) S (A), A) S (A) S (A), A) S (A) S (A).

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: Our work deals with transformations of if-then rules that describe dependencies between tiered attributes that generalize the ordinary implications of attributes in an environment in which the presence of attributes is expressed in tiers. The transformations we deal with allow us to transform a number of such dependencies into an equivalent one that is non-redundant and fulfills a strong condition of observed non-redundancy. The observed non-redundancy can be considered a desirable property because the non-redundancy of each rule in the group can be observed directly from its history. Compared to our previous results, the proposed algorithm works for arbitrary idempotent truth emphasis, which can serve as a parameter for the interpretation of the rules. As one of the consequences of the theoretical result, we have achieved that each finite object data table table table with tiered attributes (minimal context) is subject to at least one of the gradient systems that is included in this structure, and that the gradient system is also subject to at least one of the gradient contexts enclosed by this system.

referenceMentions.context: In this paper, we investigate properties of sets of graded attribute implications and extend the results presented in our recent paper [41].
implications, sometimes called fuzzy attribute implications [3], are rules describing if-then dependencies in data with graded attributes.
The rules have been proposed and investigated from the point of view of formal concept analysis (shortly, FCA [24]) with linguistic hedges [15].

In our paper, we deal with a general notion of a system of pseudo-intents which appears in the generalization of FCA which includes graded attributes and uses linguistic hedges to reduce the size of concept lattices [8].

In our previous paper [41], we have shown that considering the globalization as the hedge, each theory can be transformed into a theory which is equivalent, nonredundant, and its non-redundancy is witnessed by antecedents of the formulas in the theory.

Note for readers familiar with non-redundant bases generated from data: [41] shows that for all equivalent theories with saturated consequents, Σ given by (15) is uniquely given (considering • as the globalization) and the set of its antecedents forms a system of pseudo-intents of any formal L-context whose intents are exactly the models of Σ.

Indeed, as we have outlined here and as it is presented in [41], the procedure involves computations of least models for each formula in the complete set which may be done in polynomial time and efficient algorithms for computation of closures exist [4].

This is in contrast with computing the systems of pseudo-intents directly from a formal L-context which is known to be hard even in the classic case [19].

The goal of this paper is to show that equivalent non-redundant theories with saturated consequents and witnessed non-redundancy can be computed for any theory considering an arbitrary idempotent truth-stressing hedge and finite L, thus extending the previous results in [41] which was presented only for globalization.

In this paper, we introduce an alternative approach which is conceptually close to that in [41] but always ensures that the results are equivalent to the initial theories and have all the desired properties.

We assume finite residuated lattices as structures of truth degrees and use arbitrary idempotent truth-stressing linguistic hedges as parameters which influence the semantics of graded attribute implications. In this setting, we introduce algorithm which transforms any set of graded attribute implications into an equivalent non-redundant set of graded attribute implications with saturated consequents whose non-redundancy is witnessed by antecedents of the formulas. As a consequence, we solve the open problem regarding the existence of general systems of pseudo-intents which appear in formal concept analysis of object-attribute data with graded attributes and linguistic hedges. Furthermore, we show a polynomial-time procedure for determining bases given by general systems of pseudo-intents from sets of graded attribute implications which are complete in data.
